titleStmt.title: A dialogue, or, Rather a parley betweene Prince Ruperts dogge whose name is Puddle, and Tobies dog whose name is Pepper, &c. VVhereunto is added the challeng which Prince Griffins dogg called Towzer, hath sent to Prince Ruperts dogg Puddle, in the behalfe of honest Pepper Tobies dog. Moreover the said Prince Griffin is newly gone to Oxford to lay the wager, and to make up the match.

availability.p: To the extent possible under law, the Text Creation Partnership has waived all copyright and related or neighboring rights to this keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above, according to the terms of the CC0 1.0 Public Domain Dedication (http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/). This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: A dialogue, or, Rather a parley betweene Prince Ruperts dogge whose name is Puddle, and Tobies dog whose name is Pepper, &c. VVhereunto is added the challeng which Prince Griffins dogg called Towzer, hath sent to Prince Ruperts dogg Puddle, in the behalfe of honest Pepper Tobies dog. Moreover the said Prince Griffin is newly gone to Oxford to lay the wager, and to make up the match.
titleStmt.author: Taylor, John, 1580-1653,

notesStmt.note: Attributed to John Taylor in the Wrenn catalogue.

"Towzer" = Sir Roger L'Estrange: "On 17 Nov. 1680 he [L'Estrange] was burnt in effigy by the London mob, who gave him the sobriquet of the 'Dog Towzer', apparently in reference to reports of L'Estrange's immoralities". (Cf. DNB).
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A DIALOGVE, OR, Rather a Parley betweene Prince Ruperts Dogge who≈øe name is PVDDLE, and Tobies Dog who≈øe name is PEPPER &c.
VVhereunto is added the Challeng which Prince Griffins Dogg called Towzer, hath ≈øent to Prince Ruperts Dogg Puddle, in the behalfe of hone≈øt Pepper Tobies Dog.
Moreover the ≈øaid Prince Griffin is newly gone to Oxford to lay the wager, and to make up the MATCH.

figure.figDesc: depiction of Roundheads and Cavaliers, setting their dogs on each other

sp.p: To him pudel.
Bite him‚ñ™ peper

div.p: Printed at London for I. Smith, 1643.

div.head: A Dialogue or rather a Parley between Prince Ruperts Dog who≈øe name is Puddle, and Tobies Dog who≈øe name is Pepper, &c.
div.p: WHat yelping whindling Puppy Dog art thou?

sp.speaker: Tobies Dog.
sp.p: What bauling Shag-haird Cavalliers Dogge art thou?

sp.speaker: Pr. Rob: Dog.
sp.p: Thou ar a dogged ≈øir or Cur, grumble no more, but tell me thy name.

sp.speaker: Tob: Dog.
sp.p: I was called Tobies hou≈øe-dog, the Dog which Walker the Iron-monger ≈øo often commends for a mannerly and well bred Dog in his ≈øeverall ≈øub-lectures; my name is Pepper.

sp.speaker: Pr. Rob: Dog.
sp.p: Though your zeal be never ≈øo hot, you ≈øhall not bite me Pepper.

sp.speaker: Tob. Dog.
sp.p: He bark before I bite, and talke before I fight, I heare you are Prince Ruperts white Boy.

sp.speaker: P. Rub: Dog.
sp.p: I am none of his white Boy, my name is Puddle.

sp.speaker: Tob. Dog.
sp.p: A dirty name indeed, you are not pure enough for my company, be≈øides I hear on both ≈øides of my ‚Ä¢ ares that you are a Lap-lander or Fin-land Dog, or truly no better then a witch in the ≈øhape of a white Dogge.

sp.speaker: Pr. Rob: Dog.
sp.p: And thou art a Round-headed puppy, a fooli≈øh ≈ønarling Cur, that doth baule and rayle where≈øoever thou comme≈øt: do≈øt thou pre≈øume to confront me with thy ignorant ≈øpirit and prick-eares?

sp.speaker: Tob. Dog.
sp.p: Thou art a pro≈øane Annimall; Tobies Dog is of a better, and more reformed condition.

sp.speaker: Pr. Rob: Dog.
sp.p: A halter would reforme thee exceeding well, for thou art a cur that wilt barke again≈øt all people, nay thou art a rebellious dog, and wilt barke again≈øt the King, thou do≈øt make a ≈øtir and a ≈øtink where≈øoever thou comme≈øt, thou art Walkers Dog rather then Tobies Dog, thou and thy Ma≈øters de≈øerve nothing but a halter.

sp.speaker: Tob. Dog. Puddle;
sp.p: Come not neer me; for I can grin and bite and that boldly, though thou look like a Lyon with long ≈øhag haire, yet I fear thee not bragging Courtier, thou popi≈øh profane Dog, thou art more then halfe a divell, a kind of a ≈øpirit that doth helpe Colledges to their lo≈øt. ≈øpoons and two-eard pots, when they are lo≈øt or ≈øtolne.

sp.speaker: Pr. Rob. Dog.
sp.p: Thou art a kind of ≈øpirit too, do≈øt thou not bewitch the Sectaries to bring in Salts, Whi≈øtle, and Bodkine into Religious Lotteries, from whence I feare they ≈øhall draw nothing but blankes for their zealous affection towards the cau≈øe.

sp.speaker: Tob. Dog.
sp.p: Thou do≈øt belye the zealous brethren who being provoked and ≈øtirred up by the Spirit, thou would≈øt needs make me the per≈øwader to this religious liberty: alas I know nothing of Citie affairs, I trouble not my head with ≈øuch matters, nor do I ≈øpeak Heathen languages as you can doe.

sp.speaker: Pr. Rob. Dog.
sp.p: Sirrah, I am none of your litter nor kind; I ≈øcorn to come in compo≈øition with ≈øuch a ba≈øo dog as thou art;

sp.speaker: Tob. Dog.
sp.p: You are of Brackley breed, better to hang then to keep.

sp.speaker: Pr. Rob. Dog.
sp.p: No Sirrah, I am of a high Germain breed;

sp.speaker: Tob. Dog.
sp.p: Thou art a Reprobate, and a lying Curre; you were either whelpt in Lap-land, or el≈øe in Fin-land; where there is none but divells and Sorcerers live.

sp.speaker: Pr. Rob. Dog.
sp.p: But thou ha≈øt been a friend to Tub Lecturers, there is a number of Fellows that will expound by private ≈øpirit, and think the be≈øt colour for their knavery is Greene, and yet they have no more languages or learning then thou ha≈øt, but they are dogged duntes that will bark and baule in a Pulpit, did≈øt not thou infect Hunt the Prophet and made him rave and talk, I will not ≈øay preach, untill the Roa≈øt-beefe be burnt upon the Cooks ≈øpits and be almo≈øt one a clock.

sp.speaker: Tob. Dog.
sp.p:
I deny thy words, for while hee is preaching I am in the chimney corner ≈øleeping, I heare not a word nor care for hearing any: but it is well known that when the Kings Coun≈øell are per≈øwading His Maje≈øty to an Accommodation with his Parliament, thou being an enemy to peace and all the Parliaments good purpo≈øes, com≈øt in, and pre≈øently
they ≈øpeake of blood and war, and the de≈øtruction of London, as if they were bewitcht by thy pre≈øence.

sp.speaker: Pr. Rob. Dog.
sp.p: Nay if you talke of bewitching, who made the Apprentices and that great dogged tumult that hurried to We≈øt min≈øter grinning and ≈ønarling at all they met, and barking aloud, no Bi≈øhops, no Bi≈øhops? which put the King at White-Hall into ≈øuch a fright, that hee pre≈øently left the City full of nothing but zealous Tobies and factions Sectaries, and ≈øo went to Yorke to be more ≈øafe and ≈øecure from the rude company of pricke-eares: did not thy dogged ≈øpirit tran≈ømigrate into their plump fat bodies, and made them run like a kennell of hounds upon a hot ≈øent crying they knew not what.

sp.speaker: Tob. Dog.
sp.p: I was ignorant of their purpo≈øes, and ≈øtaid behind, for had I been willing to have been ≈øeen in the action, I would have runne before them as doggs u≈øe to do, but I remember I kept hou≈øe all that day ≈øo melancholy, and was very ≈øorry to ≈øee my ma≈øters ≈øo madde: But ≈øince you ca≈øt dirt at me, I will fling you a bone to know, it is known that at Edghill you walke invi≈øible, and directed the bullets who they ≈øhould hit, and who they ≈øhould mi≈ø≈øe, and made your Mr. Prince Rupert ≈øhott-free, and it is known that you would rather heare Ma≈ø≈øe at Oxford, then come to any private prayers or con≈øcionable Sermons: And at the delivery of the City Petition, you ≈øhewd your ≈øelfe a very malignant Dog, and trod on the Kings Maje≈øtys toe, and your Mr. Prince Rupert ≈øo earne≈øtly, as if you would have ≈øaid that you like not that the King ≈øhould return to London without his Army, and thus thou ha≈øt proved thy ≈øelfe a Cavalliers Dogge.

sp.speaker: Pr. Rob. Dog.
sp.p: Sirrah lick-di≈øh, incen≈øe me no more, for though my ≈øhaggy haire be white, it is not ≈øilver'd ever with age, it is my naturall colour, and I am ≈øtrong enough to teare thee in pieces, but I'le bite thee deep with true words, If I ≈øhould as thee how thou live≈øt, ≈øhould I not find that thou art the Sectaries familiar Dogge, and what are thy Ma≈øter, but nece≈ø≈øitous and full of debts, thou picke≈øt up crums under them, and they gaine all under the ≈øervice of the cau≈øe and Common-wealth.

sp.speaker: Tob. Dog.
sp.p: Sirrah Dog: I ≈øerve good hone≈øt men, ≈øuch as be Colonells, Captaines, and chiefe Commanders.

sp.speaker: P.R. Dog
sp.p:
I think you are any bodies Dog you lick up crums under any rou ‚Ä¢ d table, you have priviledg to come to the hou≈øe of any of the princes of the Militin, and there to know bonee and get ≈øcraps, Some of your Ma≈øters were not worth to my knowledg three yeares ≈øince, no above 5. l. if all their debts were paid, that now have 3. l. a day, others 40. s. a day, others 20. s. and ≈øome 15. s. a day; how many of them before this
bu≈øine≈ø≈øe broke in a morning, and compounded within a month for a noble in the pound: and do≈øt thou poor ≈øilly Dog thinke that the≈øe noble Princes wil once hearken or conclude to a peace; if they can have ≈øuch pay and ≈øuch gaines for nothing: many of them not worth a dog; and now who but they and their wives, that appeare in their ≈øeverall and changeable ≈øuites of apparrell, and ≈øhine like Iove and Juno.

sp.speaker: Tob. Dog.
sp.p: Sirrah, let my brave Ma≈øters alone; tell me not what they were, but what they are: They are now brave Gentlemen: leave your rayling, or el≈øe I will ≈øend but a word of my mouth and I will have a Regiment of Red-coats, and a Troop of hor≈øe, that ≈øhall quallifie your dogged humour, and make you ≈øpeake better words of them.

sp.speaker: Pr. Rob. Dog.
sp.p: I care not for your leather troops of hor≈øe, nor for your red-cotten fouldiers; I can match your be≈øt Troops when you dare and where you dare; I would have thee know that I ≈øerve and attend upon a noble King, four Princes, three Dukes, two Marque≈ø≈øes, fifty Earles, 200. Lords and Vicounts, 300. Barons, 700. Knights, and 1100 E≈øquires and Gentlemen, be≈øides common Soul ‚Ä¢ iers: The≈øe are no broken Lords, nor crackt Citizens; they ≈øerve in per≈øon and without pay, nay they beare their own charges, all out of love and loyalty to their K. and Country: But few of your Ma≈øters dur≈øt ever ≈øhew their faces till this reformed time; but held down their heads like bul-ru≈øhes; and walked up and down by night: how many hundred do you thinke, Mr. dog, that his Maje≈øty hath now in a li≈øt or a catalogue of their names of ≈øuch ≈øtout Finsbury field ≈øouldiers, and weak conditioned men in e≈øtates, above 300 of them I will a≈ø≈øure you; whom his Maje≈øty wil one day remember.

sp.speaker: Toby Dog.
sp.p: Good Puddle, be not ≈øo envious and ≈øo malicious, thus to r ‚Ä¢ ile of them you do not know, be not ≈øtill of that dogged mungrell di≈øpo≈øition good Puddle.

sp.speaker: Pr. Rob: Dog.
sp.p:
Thou ha≈øt a good memory, though thou ha≈øt but ≈øhort haire, to remember my name: yet ≈øome call me Boy, but my name is Puddle: And I can do ≈øtrange things, and change my ≈øelfe into many ≈øhapes: I come into your City divers times, and heare the common votes of the vulgar, then I go to the Ordinaries and take notice what newes pa≈ø≈øes there for current, any one may almo≈øt di≈øcover me if they doe but touch me, I do to grumble and am of the dogged di≈øpo≈øition, and if any one ob≈øerve or hear a Gentleman call for a di≈øh of broth, and his Ordinary of Rumps and Kidneyes, they may be a≈ø≈øured it is I; The other night for giving of two pence to a red bearded fellow one Mr. P ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ es who was made Corporal for that night, who then ≈øtood neer the Exchang, I had the word given mee by him, and I pa≈øt freely: Another time I pa≈øt by the watch
like a Fidler, and was never examined; and ≈øo likewi≈øe for a ≈ømall matter at your Court of Guards, for all your vigilant Sentinells.

sp.speaker: Toby Dog.
sp.p: O intollerable; if the City be not looked too better, wee ≈øhall be all betrayed.

sp.speaker: Pr. Rup. Dog.
sp.p: Nay more then this can I doe, and have done, at the Ia≈øt generall meeting at Guild-Hall, I hired Arthur Shuttle a Procters Clerk to go into Long-lane and procure an Aldermans gowne, and come to Guild-Hall, though it was ≈øo narrowly looked to, to get in, and there by his meanes to beget a faction, and ≈øo a tumult, and at length to have faln to blows among≈øt your ≈øelves, that our Army in the meane time might have come in and plaid their part to the purpo≈øe. It was I that cau≈øed that mercinary fellow Robert Blague to write letters of intelligence between both Armies, and for his reward he had 50. pound a moneth from each Army: I per≈øwaded Blague to give intelligence to the Earle of E≈ø≈øex in what part of the army the Kings be≈øt Regiment was placed, and in what place the Lord Generall would bee at the fight, and where the Kings Standard would be placed. Then on the other ≈øide I put it into the heart of the Kings ≈øouldiers after the fir≈øt fireing to fall to pillaging and plundering the Earl of E≈ø≈øex his Coach and Waggons where all his trea≈øure was to pay his ≈øouldiers, which the did, and in plundering the Coach, there was the mi≈øcreant Blagues letter found with his name at it of the former intelligence, which was taken and carried to the King, which the King ≈øaw and read, for which Blague had his ju≈øt reward, even a rope; with chains to boot.

I advi≈øed Mr. Ma≈øton who is the Earl of Carnarvans Chaplain to make that book which our army do ≈øo hug and laugh at, called the Complaint to the Hou≈øe of Commons: I put it into ≈øome of the malignant Citizens heads, as your Ma≈øters call them, to ≈øurprize the Tower, and to get al the Ordnance into their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion: but that failing, I have ≈øhewed them another ≈øtratagem how to be revenged on the City for their Robellion; you may ≈øee Pepper what power and skill I have in magicke Spells; Nay though the Gentleman did preach not above a week before the Hou≈øe of Commons, but his Sermon being not liked, and he little or no thanks be≈øtowed on him, I wi≈øhed him to write that invective book: I have done divers of the≈øe exploits, and have many more plots yet undi≈øcovered.

sp.speaker: Toby Dog.
sp.p: Learned Mr. Puddle do but reveal ≈øome of the≈øe plots to me and I will ever be your creature.

sp.speaker: Pr. Rup. Dog.
sp.p: Pepper, take but your oath that you will not di≈øcover it till ≈øuch a time, and I will:

sp.speaker: Toby Dog.
sp.p: I will ≈øwear any thing you will have me to do.

sp.speaker: Pr. Rup. Dog.
sp.p: You ≈øhall take the new oath which our Cavalliers do give to all the pri≈øoners which they took at Cice≈øter, before they go away from Oxford which if you doe, I will then reveal the plot.

sp.speaker: Toby Dog.
sp.p: I have taken i ‚Ä¢ , and ≈øworn to the oath.

sp.speaker: Pr. Rup. Dog.
sp.p: Then this is the plot. The next high or ≈øpring tide, when the moon is at the full, wil your City be drowned, and I will tel you how vand which way: The City malignants do intend to under-mine the Rider of Thames, and it is to be begun on Seuthwark ≈øide, and when it is undermined, to lay in 1000. barrells of Gun-powder, 500. barres of Iron, and 600. tun of Stones; and when the tyde or water is at the highe≈øt, then to ≈øet fire on the Gun-powder and blow up the River and ≈øo drown the City and all the Round-heads; and for the Malignants they ≈øhal have all notice of it before; and ≈øhall be known by their white tybonds about their ri≈øts; only I have given Iohn Taylor the Water-Poet notice of it, to ≈øave him≈øelfe by his boate, or be in ≈øome other place at that time and ≈øea≈øon, becau≈øe hee is my Ma≈øters Vncles ancient ≈øervant, and a good Fellow.

sp.speaker: Toby Dog.
sp.p: I begin to halt in my opinion, and would be willingly converted, I get nothing here but at great mens hou≈øes, and now Lent is comming I ≈øhall lo≈øe my fat, among≈øt the Round-heads; for they cate up all, and leave me nothing unle≈ø≈øe I can fill my belly with the ≈ømell of meate, they are expounders and Teachers, but I de≈øire to be better ≈øedd then taught.

sp.speaker: P. Rup. Dog.
sp.p: Then follow my coun≈øell, change your affections, & when you ≈øee a Round-head, barke at him as he walks along the ≈øtreets.

sp.speaker: Toby Dog.
sp.p: So I may have by brains beat out.

sp.speaker: P. Rup. Dog.
sp.p: Then convey your ≈øelfe down to Oxford, but fir≈øt you mu≈øt do as I in≈øtruct you, and recant your errours, and both ≈øay and doe as I in≈øtruct you; and I will give you an invi≈øible ≈øhape, ≈øo that none ≈øhall ≈øee you if you plea≈øe.

sp.speaker: Toby Dog.
sp.p: I am your ≈øervant to run at your command.

sp.speaker: P. Rup. Dog.
sp.p: Fir≈øt you mu≈øt deny all Round-heads.

sp.speaker: Toby Dog.
sp.p: I deny and defie all Round-heads.

sp.speaker: P. Rup. Dog.
sp.p: I defie all Tub-lecturers.

sp.speaker: Toby Dog.
sp.p: All Tub-lecturers I defie.

sp.speaker: Pr. Rup. Dog.
sp.p: I will barke again≈øt all Conventicles, and never love any Browni≈øt or any of the zealous Brethren, but from the teeth outwards.

sp.speaker: Toby Dog.
sp.p: I will always be Inapping and ≈ønarling at them.

sp.speaker: P. Ruperts Dog.
sp.p: Now confirme it with an Oath in blowing your no≈øe backewards, and letting a fart, and ≈øay a fart for all Sectaries.

sp.speaker: Toby Dog.
sp.p: I will ≈øtraine hard but I will do it, there is a fart for them all.

sp.speaker: Pr. Rup. Dog.
sp.p: But I gave you no command to ≈øtink.

sp.speaker: Toby Dog.
sp.p: That makes the Obligation the ≈øtronger: is there any thing more to make me a perfect Cavallier.

sp.speaker: Pr. Rup. Dog.
sp.p: Yes, you mu≈øt be beholding to a di≈øgui≈øe, for if you be a Cavallier you mu≈øt weare long haire, I can helpe you to the wool of a Sheepeshead which will ≈øerve you very well for a Perewigg, and then I will pre≈øent thee to my Ma≈øter for a new and round, ≈øound Cavallier.

sp.speaker: Toby Do.
sp.l: Get me my di≈øgui≈øe, my mind is chang'd already, let us be friends,
For now old Tobies Dog doth thinke it better,
To change him≈øelfe to Cavallier Pepper.

div.head: The Challenge which Prince Griffins Dogge called Towzer, hath ≈øent to Prince Ruperts dog who≈øe name is Puddle, daring him to meet him at the Pari≈øh Garden this pre≈øent Lent to try a combate before the Wor≈øhipfull the Beares, who are appointed to be their Judges in that Ca≈øe.
div.p: THou worme of Wickedne≈ø≈øe, fritter of Folly, ≈øpawn of doggedne≈ø≈øe, and piece of mungrell ≈øtuffe; in regard of thy ba≈øe grumbling words and bawling again≈øt thy betters. Be≈øides that, is hone≈øt Pepper Tobies Dogge your match, no, he is too milde for thee; thou ≈øhould have given notice of your Treaty and di≈øcour≈øe to me who am thy equall, thou ≈øhould≈øt have found enough of me, for I will have thee know, that I eate as good Rumps and Kidneyes as ever thou, ba≈øe cur do≈øt: when I have you at the place appointed, I will ≈øo rump you, and ≈øo frump you, that I will leave you never a rumpe nor yet a kidney, no not with a heart as big as a hen or chickins: I doe now with open mouth defie thee and all thy proceedings, and doe challenge thee to meet me at the place before mentioned, there will I fight, tug, and teare thee in a ≈øingle combate, where I mean to read thee in pieces, and be revenged on thee ba≈øe cur. And although I hear thou art impenitrable and likewi≈øe be≈ømeared over with inchaunted oyle, ≈øo that no weapon, buller, nor ≈øword can enter thee to make thee bleed; yet I haue teeth which I have newly whetted ≈øhall ≈øo fe≈øten and teare your German or Fin-land hide limb-meale, and then flea thy skin and hang it on the hedg, & give thy pomperd fle≈øh to tho≈øe Iudges which we are to fight before (namely the Wor≈øhipfull the Bears,) to ≈øatisfie their hungry mawes this Lent; let me hear your dogged an≈øwer, or el≈øe I wil proclaim thee coward in print, and ≈øet thy name upon every whipping po≈øt and pi≈ø≈øing place, for all the dogs in the Town to lift up their legs to pi≈ø≈øe again≈øt: Expect no favour from mee, nor will I from you: I will end the difference, I wil have no Out-landi≈øh cur domineer in our Land. So ≈øaith your ≈øurley foe Towzer, and ≈øervant to Primes Cri≈ø≈øin.
